articles.title: Grass fire contained, Highway 1A reopened near Mini Thni, Alta.: RCMP
articles.author: Brendan Ellis
articles.summary: There was a grass fire west of Ghost lake, north of Highway 1A, on February 25, 2025. The cause of the fire was not immediately known, but it could have been caused by a lightning strike. The fire is still under control today.

articles.title: School Districts Announce Helene Make-up Days
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene forced upstate schools to make some major adjustments because of the hurricane. Upstate schools have to make major adjustments due to the hurricane Helene.      Â  “The Weather Channel’s" Weather Channel's Weather Channel is live.

articles.title: Toronto residents worry melting snow will lead to flooding
articles.summary: Warm temperatures cause snow to melt in Toronto. Some residents worry about the impact on their homes. CBC's Britnei Bilhete has more on the story on CBC's "This is Life in Toronto". iReport.com: What do you think? Share your thoughts.

articles.title: Calculating the economic cost of climate change is tricky, even futile – it's also a distraction
articles.summary: Climate change is here, it's real and it increasingly affects us all. The economic costs of climate change are small. Some areas experience more extreme impacts than others, exacerbating social and economic disparities. The relationship between temperature and socioeconomic outcomes can be modelled using a "dose-response" function.

articles.title: Peru: Rainy season leaves 62 dead, 9 missing, and 23,743 affected
articles.summary: Since the official start of the rainy season in December 2024, 62 people have died, nine are missing and 23,743 have been affected due to heavy rainfall. Moderate to extreme rainfall has affected 103,791 people, while 11,861 others have had their livelihoods impacted. 14 people died as a result of lightning storms in Huancavelica and Cusco regions, while 13 people died in a riverboat accident in Puno region. 7 classrooms destroyed, 26 declared uninhabitable, 109 damaged, 27 healthcare facilities affected, 323 km of local roads destroyed and 2,537 km damaged.

articles.title: Defence head warns of ‘unpredictable global setting' amid Chinese warships saga
articles.author: Joseph Olbrycht-Palmer
articles.summary: Greg Moriarty, Secretary of Defence, is warning of an increasingly uncertain world. China's move to deploy warships off Australia's east coast and the People's Liberation Army's live fire drills in the Tasman Sea are just a few examples of recent security shifts. The ADF had been tracking the Chinese ships off the Queensland coast nearly two weeks ago.

articles.title: Calls for more recovery funding as floodwaters leave craters on north Queensland farms
articles.author: Brooke  Tindall
articles.summary: Floodwater destroyed Wal Giordani's farm in four days. Ramon Jayo estimates it will cost as much as $300,000 to rebuild the washed-out creek bed on his farm. The federal government has activated Category C Disaster Recovery Funding Arrangements to help with the clean-up. Queensland Cane, Agriculture and Renewables is pushing for Premier David Crisafulli and PM Anthony Albanese to activate Category D funding.

articles.title: Warming Kerala sea waters pushing mackerel & sardines to Gujarat coast
articles.author: Nimesh Khakhariya
articles.summary: Gujarat's fishermen are landing a lot of mackerel and sardines. The pelagic species have been moving northwards and towards Gujarat in the past years, pushed by a slight but key change in water temperatures along Kerala's coast. In three years, the landing of these species on the Gujarat coast has seen an approximate three-to-four-fold increase from 10,000 tonnes.

articles.title: SPECIAL REPORT: Climate change's impact to the Desert Southwest
articles.author: Melissa Zaremba
articles.summary: 2024 was the hottest summer on record for the Desert Southwest and Earth reached its warmest temperature ever. Experts say climate change is the reason for the rising temperatures and is affecting our planet. The extra heat also poses challenges to local agriculture and crops. Expert: Planting more trees, recycling, using reusable items, and carpooling could help slow the warming trend.

articles.title: Claim: Standard of Living to Soar by 176% by 2100 if No Climate Action
articles.author: Eric Worrall
articles.summary: Professor Dennis Wesselbaum thinks we should act on climate change, but economic harm is not a good justification for doing so. Eric Worrall disagrees with some of the professor's ideas. Eric reckons saving the environment is more important than economic benefits.

articles.title: China pledges global cooperation to address climate change
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: China is willing to work with all parties to jointly address the challenges of extreme weather and climate risks, says Chen Zhenlin, head of the China Meteorological Administration. Chen made the remarks at the 62nd session of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) that opened on Monday in Hangzhou.

articles.title: Africa set to reach 1.5 C climate change threshold by 2040 even under low emission scenarios
articles.author: Science Daily
articles.summary: New research suggests that all five subregions of Africa will breach the 1.5 C climate change threshold by 2040 even under low emission scenarios. The limit is the limit stipulated by the Paris Agreement, as stated by the UNFCCC. The research is based on new climate change scenarios.

articles.title: No immediate flooding concerns from melting, rain, NPCA says
articles.author: Mike Zettel
articles.summary: There is no immediate concern about flooding in Niagara Peninsula due to rapidly rising temperatures and rain. Conservation Authority is keeping an eye on local waterways but does not expect to issue a flood warning at this time.      .   -

articles.title: No immediate flooding concerns from melting snow, rain: NPCA
articles.author: Mike Zettel
articles.summary: There is no immediate concern about flooding in Niagara Peninsula Conservation Authority. The authority does not expect to issue a flood warning at this time. There are puddles on streets that were once covered in ice. The authorities is keeping an eye on local waterways, but so far it is not a concern.

articles.title: Landmark polar sciences experiment announced for next decade
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: The International Polar Year will run for the fifth time in history. It is humanity's oldest and longest-running climate experiment. The IPY is the longest-lasting and most successful experiment in the history of humanity's history. The IPUY runs every five years.

articles.title: Climate change and poisonings take toll on beachfront landmarks
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Trees are facing threats from humans and dry weather, a university researcher says. The trees have become icons of Australian beachfronts and are threatened by human activity and the weather, he adds. The researcher is a researcher at the University of Melbourne.

articles.title: Barrier Island mayors send letter to President Trump asking for help with nourishment projects
articles.author: Casey Albritton
articles.summary: Barrier Island mayors are asking President Trump for help getting re-nourishment projects along their beaches. They want to reduce the length of property easements from never ending to just two years so they could be renewed for each new nourishment project. The Army Corps of Engineers won't move sand onto Pinellas County beaches without 100% compliance.

articles.title: Oman Climate Week showcases youth initiatives for environment protection
articles.author: ONA
articles.summary: The exhibition on the sidelines of Oman Climate Week is showcasing the latest innovations and technologies in the field of climate change and environment conservation. The event is taking place at the Oman Convention and Exhibition Centre. Qatar Foundation-affiliated centre named Earthna presents its vision and research findings on environmental and sustainability issues. Earthna informs participants of the event about the White Papers Initiative 2024.

articles.title: New Study: Satellite Data Shows Ocean Evaporation Declining, Upends Climate Models
articles.author: Thomas Richard
articles.summary: A study published in PNAS confirmed climate models fail to simulate what happens in the real world concerning fundamental climate change variables like water vapor. In 2020, Dr. Koutsoyiannis published a paper indicating no increasing trend in global specific humidity since 2008, 1980, or even the late 1940s as predicted by climate models.

articles.title: The struggle of South African schools against extreme weather
articles.author: Takudzwa Pongweni
articles.summary: Severe weather hit South Africa last week, bringing torrential rains, flash flooding and reports of tornadoes. In North West province, 27 schools were affected, some were rendered inaccessible and others damaged. In Limpopo's Waterberg district, schools were forced to close for a week due to severe flooding. In the Eastern Cape, two pupils were swept away by floodwaters. Unicef warned that the global education system was unprepared to handle the impacts of extreme weather events.

articles.title: Farmers: Cold snap inflicts heavy damage to Jordan Valley crops
articles.author: //Petra//SS
articles.summary: A cold snap that hit Jordan early Tuesday damaged large crops in the Northern Jordan Valley. Farmers complained about heavy damage to exposed vegetables, banana trees, tropical fruits, avocado and papaya, and citrus crops. They called on authorities to assess frost-damaged crops and compensate them to survive the current season.

articles.title: Donald Trump broke the law by removing climate change references from USDA websites, lawsuit alleges
articles.author: Justine Calma
articles.summary: The US Department of Agriculture purged information about climate change from its websites and threatened organic farmers' livelihoods, according to a new lawsuit. The suit was filed on behalf of the Northeast Organic Farming Association of New York (NOFA-NY) and two environmental groups. The administration has been racing to destroy public resources that address climate change and civil rights, sparking legal battles.

articles.title: COE warns of deteriorating coastal conditions due to strong winds
articles.author: Merit Designs Consulting Group
articles.summary: Strong winds are affecting the Dominican Republic's coasts. Vessel operators are advised to navigate only near the shore, especially between Cabo San Rafael and Saona Island. On the Atlantic coast, vessel operators are urged to exercise caution and avoid offshore travel due to hazardous waves and strong winds.

articles.title: Rwenzori glaciers melt as temperatures keep rising
articles.summary: Kasese district in Uganda is one of the most affected areas by climate change. There has been a rise in the frequency and intensity of disasters such as flooding, mudslides, and landslides. Today, we examine the human toll of these floods in Kasese and explore interventions aimed at helping communities build resilience against recurring disasters.

articles.title: Melting glaciers threaten global water security
articles.summary: Glaciers hold vast amounts of fresh water that are essential for people and the environment. An international research team tracked changes in nearly 275,000 glaciers since the early 2000s. Melting glaciers are linked to a rise in sea level of 18mm. The sub-Antarctic islands are losing around 1.5% of their mass.

articles.title: Warmth expected to last a long while
articles.summary: Warm weather is expected to last for the next few days. Jodi Hughes has a look at the five-day forecast from the Sky Watch Weather Centre. It's expected to be warm and sunny for the whole of the next five days, with highs of around 30 degrees.

articles.title: Study reveals Africa will reach 1.5C climate change threshold by 2040 even under low emission scenarios
articles.author: Science X staff
articles.summary: All five subregions of Africa will breach the 1.5°C climate change threshold by 2040 even under low emissions scenarios. Just transition pathways for Africa's agriculture are urgently required for sustainable production systems that enhance food security and poverty reduction, while optimizing mitigation co-benefits.

articles.title: The biggest worry for the Australian Grand Prix CEO
articles.author: Tony Davis
articles.summary: Travis Auld is the chief executive officer of the Australian Grand Prix Corporation. His main worry is keeping the event on the road, given the cost of hosting global events is skyrocketing. 'It has grown significantly since COVID, so our ability to manage pricing and keep the event accessible is something we're very focused on,' he says.

articles.title: CNBC Claims Climate Change Is Causing A Housing Market Collapse. Real Data Says No
articles.author: H. Sterling Burnett
articles.summary: CNBC published an article claiming that climate change is threatening to cause a housing market collapse. Data show no climate change-induced extreme weather, and the markets CNBC cites as being threatened with decline have seen tremendous growth in housing prices as the Earth has modestly warmed. The U.N.'s most recent report from IPCC verifies that wildfire, hurricane, and flood trends are either flat or have declined in recent years.

articles.title: Dozens dead as hail, rain hit two provinces in Afghanistan: officials
articles.author: Rabiul Islam
articles.summary: Twenty-nine people died in two provinces in Afghanistan due to hail and heavy rain. The victims are members of two families who had gone for a picnic. Afghanistan is ranked as the country sixth most vulnerable to climate crisis due to drought, floods, land degradation and declining agricultural productivity.

articles.title: Flags of Hope on display in Lansing
articles.summary: Lansing was one of the hardest hit communities in Ashe County after Hurricane Helene flooded the area last year. Now flags are flying along the fence rail and the fronts of businesses along NC Highway 194 to bring messages of hope and positivity to the Lansing community.

articles.title: Deadly hailstorm in Afghanistan claims 29 lives
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: At least 29 people died in two provinces in Afghanistan due to hail and heavy rain. In Farah, 21 people were killed and six others were injured because of hail. In Kandahar, 8 people died due to heavy rain and a roof collapsed on a family, killing one woman and three children. Afghanistan is vulnerable to climate change.

articles.title: New research links storm season intensity in B.C. with ocean acidification in Strait of Georgia
articles.author: Tiffany Crawford
articles.summary: Ocean acidification has potentially disastrous effects on marine ecosystems and fisheries. Ocean water in the Pacific Northwest is more vulnerable to rapid acidification because it's old and cold. B.C.'s ocean acidification and hypoxia action plan, released in 2023, notes that it poses a significant threat to aquaculture and wild capture fisheries.

articles.title: Afghanistan: Heavy rainfall kills 29 people, victims swept away by floodwaters
articles.summary: As many as 29 people died in Afghanistan on Tuesday as heavy rains lashed parts of the country. 21 died in the province of Farah, while eight others died in Kandahar. Farah's Disaster Management Department said that the victims were members of two families who were out for a picnic when downpours caused a flood-like situation. In Kandahar, the victims included women and children who were swept away by floodwaters and one woman who was washing clothes was killed.

articles.title: Climate Change Could Force 113mln Africans to Flee Their Homes by 2050 (report)
articles.author: Ecofin Agency
articles.summary: By 2050, 113 million Africans may be forced to leave their homes and lands due to extreme weather events caused by climate change. The number of Africans displaced by climate-related disasters surged by 600% between 2009 and 2023. Africa has some of the world's most progressive legal frameworks to protect climate refugees.

articles.title: Letter: Climate change existed before humanity
articles.author: Montgomery Advertiser
articles.summary: Climate change on earth exists. It has always existed. It existed before industrialization and before humanity. There were ice ages when glaciers covered much of the Earth. There was a time when there was no industrialization. It is indisputable that there is climate change.

articles.title: IPCC's 62 session starts in Hangzhou
articles.author: Interfax-Ukraine
articles.summary: The 62nd session of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) started its work in Hangzhou. The current session aims to agree on the content of the parts of the three working groups to the Seventh Assessment Report (AR7) and the Methodological Report on Carbon Dioxide Removal, Utilization and Storage Technologies.

articles.title: Letter: Climate change existed before humanity
articles.author: Daniel Haullman
articles.summary: Daniel Haulman believes that climate change on earth has always existed. He is certain that it is now affected by human activity more than before industrialization. Even if there were no humans on the earth, there would still be climate change because of factors other than human activity.

articles.title: Climate change shrinking glaciers faster than ever; 7 trillion tons lost since 2000
articles.author: SETH BORENSTEIN
articles.summary: Climate change is accelerating the melting of the world's mountain glaciers, according to a massive new study. The world's glaciers have lost more than 7 trillion tons of ice (6.5 trillion metric tons) since 2000. In the last few years, the melt has accelerated even more, hitting a record 604 billion tons in 2023.

articles.title: Severe frost in Cyprus devastates crops, farmers face losses
articles.summary: The recent frost in Cyprus has had a severe impact on agricultural products in various regions. The Ministry of Agriculture is currently assessing the situation and working with farmers to protect their crops as much as possible. Banana growers in the Paphos region are also facing considerable challenges due to the cold weather.

articles.title: Climate change has made heatwaves more deadly
articles.summary: A recent study from The University of Queensland confirms that human-driven climate change has increased heatwave deaths by 20%. Urban areas are particularly at risk from heatwaves due to high population densities and large infrastructure like roads, buildings, and transport systems. Urban dwellers with lower incomes, less education, diabetes, and limited healthcare access are especially vulnerable to heat surges.

articles.title: Climate Change: 113 Million Africans Could Be Displaced by 2050
articles.author: archyde
articles.summary: By 2050, an estimated 113 million Africans could be forced to migrate due to climate change impacts. Africa has some of the world's most progressive legal frameworks for protecting climate refugees. However, African countries have struggled to effectively implement these legal frameworks. Africa's largest U.N. peacekeeping missions are stationed in the most vulnerable countries.

articles.title: How AI Is Changing the Way We Fight Climate Change
articles.author: John Dyson
articles.summary: Artificial Intelligence is transforming our approach to the fight against climate change. It helps in predicting weather patterns with enhanced accuracy and enhancing energy efficiency. It's also helping farmers adapt by developing sustainable farming practices. AI is also helping scientists sift through historical climate records and model future scenarios.

articles.title: Neither lions nor sharks – this is the animal that all Australians fear for this reason
articles.summary: The cassowary is one of the largest birds on the planet. It's a prehistoric-looking creature with a weaponized toe and a no-nonsense attitude. Cassowaries play a crucial role in keeping rainforests thriving. They are the world's largest fruit-loving bird. Their digestive system spreads seeds far and wide, helping forests regenerate. The male takes full responsibility for raising their chicks.

articles.title: Uganda Grapples With Extreme Heat As Meteorologists Warn of Prolonged Temperatures
articles.author: Julius Kitone
articles.summary: Temperatures in some parts of Uganda are surpassing 35°C. The heatwave is likely to last until March. Health experts report an increase in heat-related illnesses, including dehydration and heat stroke. Farmers are already feeling the impact, with crops wilting under the prolonged heat and delayed rains. Environmental activists urge the government to act.

articles.title: Groups Sue USDA for Censoring Climate-Related Content on Website
articles.author: Democracy Now
articles.summary: Farmworker and environmental groups are suing the Trump administration over its removal of climate change-related information on the USDA's website. The lawsuit accuses the USDA of harming farmers' livelihoods by removing the information. The USDA denies the allegations.   .

articles.title: Scientists fear continent could 'crash into' Asia – and result will change world forever
articles.author: Liam McInerney
articles.summary: Australia is moving northwards 2.8 inches every year and is on a collision course with Asia. The resulting geological changes and landscape reshaping will be monumental. Australia's movement is already having an impact, with increased seismic activity in the region. Professor Zheng-Xiang Li, of Curtin University, has been studying this for years.

articles.title: Rigged: Researchers Notice Very Special Item Missing from 82 Separate 'Climate Science' Studies
articles.author: C. Douglas Golden
articles.summary: In a new study, researchers found that between 1994-2023, none of the 82 'climate science' papers they identified had a financial or non-financial conflict of interest disclosure from at least one author. Funding from non-governmental organizations was correlated with finding 'a positive association between climate change and geophysical characteristics of hurricanes as a research outcomes'

articles.title: Climate Justice Stir Makes Right Noises
articles.author: Roseina Coutinho
articles.summary: There is a growing gap between rich and poor in the world. The rich are responsible for half of all global emissions, while the poorest 50% contribute less than 10%. The movement seeks to strike a balance between economic growth and ecological responsibility. The Green New Deal seeks to amalgamate both climate change and inequality.

articles.title: Staff photos of the week: Sand and ice, wind farm, shellfishing, Cape Cod Canal at sunset
articles.author: Merrily Cassidy
articles.summary: The We Choose to Fight protest was held at Peg Noonan Park in Falmouth Monday afternoon. The event was hosted by Indivisible Upper Cape, Falmouth Immigrant Rights Coalition, the Coalition for Social Justice and other advocacy groups. About a half dozen members from the United Cape Patriots were in front of the Falmouth Public Library during the rally.

articles.title: I bought a bird table and instantly regretted it - and you might have made the same error
articles.author: Rom Preston-Ellis
articles.summary: There is a decline of UK bird populations since the 1970s. Insect populations - a main food source for birds - are thought to have dropped by 40%. Alex Evans bought a bird table in a garden centre for £22. RSPB has pulled flat bird tables from sale due to concerns they could contribute to the spread of diseases.

articles.title: Boiling Point: Want to fight climate change? Then talk about climate change
articles.author: The Los Angeles Times
articles.summary: People should not annoy their friends and family by talking about climate change constantly. Large majorities of Americans support climate change progress.    - John Sutter, author of "The Case for Action on Climate Change", says it's a good idea to talk about it.

articles.title: A History of Global Mean Surface Temperatures
articles.author: Glen Asher
articles.summary: Geoscientist explains the long-term trends of global temperatures well before the modern age. The Earth's temperature has varied between 11 degrees Celsius and 36 degrees Celsius over the past 485 million years. Carbon dioxide exerts dominant control over the climate during the Phanerozoic era.

articles.title: Boiling Point: Want to fight climate change? Then talk about climate change
articles.author: Sammy Roth Climate Columnist
articles.summary: In the latest poll, 73% of Americans think global warming is happening and 60% know it's mostly human-caused. Nearly two-thirds of Americans are worried about climate change consequences. Most people don't talk about global warming with their friends and family.

articles.title: US officials have been absent from global climate forums during Trump 2.0
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: US officials have missed recent international climate forums. There are concerns about a significant shift from Donald Trump's stance on international climate issues. The move is 'deeply troubling' and 'unfair one-sided' according to Donald Trump. He has criticised the Paris climate accord.

articles.title: Pickens Co. School District announce Helene make-up days
articles.author: Nikolette Miller
articles.summary: The School District of Pickens County announced calendar updates regarding make-up days due to Hurricane Helene. Students will make up school on Friday, April 21, Friday, May 22, Saturday, May 23 and Friday, Feb. 14. The days will be in person due to SC Department of Education's Handbook.

articles.title: Hurricane Helene makeup days announced for students in Pickens County
articles.author: Anisa Snipes
articles.summary: The School District of Pickens County has adjusted the 2024-25 school calendar to make up some of the days missed during Hurricane Helene. Six instructional days were missed due to the hurricane. South Carolina law requires all instructional days missing due to extreme weather or other disruptions to be made up.

articles.title: Two continents will collide and reshape Earth
articles.summary: Two continents are drifting at a rate of 7 centimeters per year. Australia broke away from Antarctica 80 million years ago and its northward drift has continued ever since. Scientists predict that Australia will collide with Asia in hundreds of millions of years. The convergence of the two continents is expected to increase seismic activity and Australia's climate could be affected.

articles.title: Why Florida Might Be Uninhabitable in 50 Years
articles.author: Ayman Rani Ahmed
articles.summary: In 50 years Florida might be uninhabitable due to climate change. Rising sea levels, changing rainfall patterns, droughts, and more frequent hurricanes are some of the main issues facing the Sunshine State. Florida can take steps to prepare and adapt by investing in sustainable water management and building codes.

articles.title: Expanding climate action beyond green energy
articles.author: Arindam Banerjee
articles.summary: The Copernicus Climate Change Service has marked 2024 as the first year to cross the 1.5°C temperature threshold defined by the Paris Agreement. The country's high vulnerability to the climate crisis is going to affect the Indian populace in the coming years. The Rural Prosperity and Resilience programme aims to aid climate-resistant crop yield and sustainable agriculture. The focus on the agri-economy leaves out the prospect of diversification of trade and livelihood opportunities in rural areas.

articles.title: New Arlington climate policy adopted as advocates press for aggressive action
articles.author: Scott McCaffrey
articles.summary: Arlington County Board adopted a new policy statement on the county's response to changing climate conditions. The policy says consideration of climate impacts will occur before planning efforts. A work plan on developing a climate action plan to implement broader policies is set to be detailed this week. It will go into effect for fiscal 2027 budget planning next year.

articles.title: A Mining Billionaire's Case for Ditching Fossil Fuels
articles.author: Time Magazine
articles.summary: Andrew Forrest is a climate activist and a mining magnate. He has lunch with Andrew Forrest. Forrest's rugged features do not reflect the arid climate. Forrest believes that if you think you can't go green, then you're right.

articles.title: Migratory birds leave Bhitarkanika as temperature soars in Odisha
articles.author: Odishatv Bureau
articles.summary: Migratory birds are leaving Bhitarakanika National Park early this year due to the rise in temperature and the onset of early summer in Odisha. More than 1.51 lakh migratory birds from 118 species made Bhitarkanika their temporary home this year.

articles.title: The Impact Of Modern Technology In Australia
articles.summary: Australia is one of the top 10 biggest developed countries of the world. Many international students go to Australia for further studies. Australia is famous for its scientific research and methodology instruments.   .   for students from Nepal, Bangladesh, Pakistani, Bhutanese, Chinese, Indian and many more countries.

articles.title: A Mining Billionaire's Case for Ditching Fossil Fuels
articles.summary: Andrew Forrest is an Australian mining magnate and a strong advocate for climate change. His company, Fortescue, will stop using fossil fuels in its land-based operations entirely by 2030. To make it happen, in 2022 the company launched a $6 billion capital investment in electric mining trucks. Al Gore says business leaders need to act with the same determination and sense of purpose as Andrew Forrest.

articles.title: Reader's View: Column on climate change deceptive, incomplete
articles.summary: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change finds human-caused climate change is already affecting many weather and climate extremes in every region across the globe. It has led to widespread adverse impacts and related losses and damages to nature and people. John McDonald is from Duluth.

articles.title: Southwest monsoon winds cause houses to collapse in Mekong Delta
articles.author: SGGPO
articles.summary: Strong southwest monsoon winds have damaged three homes in Soc Trang Province's Long Phu District. Locals mobilized militia and youth forces to help people move their belongings. The northeast monsoon is expected to maintain its strong intensity in southern sea areas through February 26.

articles.title: Powys housing scheme opponents pinning hopes on Welsh Government call-in
articles.summary: 'It has wrongly remained on the Local Development Plan (LDP) for 12 years. The effects of climate change and increased frequency and intensity of rainfall are taken into account. 'It is more than locally important. It has been wrongly on the LDP for far too long'

articles.title: World's biggest iceberg on collision course with South Georgia – here's what might happen next
articles.author: Deputy Editor
articles.summary: Iceberg A23a broke off the Filchner ice sheet in the Weddell Sea in 1986 and is heading towards South Georgia. South Georgia is an important breeding ground for penguins, seals and albatrosses. If the iceberg collided with the island, it could block many animals' access to breeding grounds and foraging waters.

articles.title: Murcia tackles environmental challenges
articles.author: Catherine McGeer
articles.summary: Murcia will host Spain's first-ever Climate Detectives Summit on April 3-4. The event is part of the European Space Agency's (ESA) ESERO Spain project. Students aged up to 19 from across Spain will come together to study climate-related problems in their communities and suggest real solutions.

articles.title: Met Department forecasts 2 - 4 degrees C rise in maximum temperatures in Andhra Pradesh
articles.author: PTI
articles.summary: Temperatures are likely to be above 2 to 4 degrees Celsius above normal over the next two days and up to 3 degrees Celsius thereafter for another three days in parts of Andhra Pradesh. Lower tropospheric easterly and south easterlies winds are prevailing over Coastal and Rayalaseema.

articles.title: Africa to Hit 1.5C Climate Threshold by 2040
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: All five subregions of Africa will breach the 1.5°C climate change threshold by 2040 even under low emission scenarios. Just transition pathways for Africa's agriculture are urgently required for sustainable production systems that enhance food security and poverty reduction, while optimising mitigation co-benefits.

articles.title: Researchers issue urgent warning about unexpected challenges in HIV prevention: 'There remains a significant, persisting lack of knowledge'
articles.author: Zachary Ehrmann
articles.summary: Extreme weather events such as droughts, floods and hurricanes are creating serious challenges for HIV prevention and treatment worldwide. More than 54% of people with HIV live in Eastern and Southern Africa. Extreme weather events can increase poverty and food insecurity, which in turn can lead to increased HIV transmission risks and worse health outcomes for those already living with HIV.

articles.title: Opinion: Enter sustainable DEVILopment
articles.author: Bradly Gill
articles.summary: Nik Kowsar has been an evangelist for sustainable development for years. Now he believes the UN's Sustainable Development Goals have been ineffective. The UN set the alarm clock for 2030, and in 2023, we've graduated from global warming to global boiling. Oil companies, mega-corporations, and banks are all in on the game.

articles.title: Abg Jo: Bintulu's unprecedented ‘great flood' due to 900mm of rain in a single day
articles.author: Bp Editor
articles.summary: There was a great flood in Bintulu town due to 900mm of rain that fell within a single day. Premier Abang Johari reaffirmed Sarawak's policy towards decarbonisation and sustainability in the midst of the global climate change. He said the world is dangerously close to breaching the 1.5 degrees Celsius warming threshold.

articles.title: Migratory birds are leaving Odisha's Bhitarkanika National Park early. Here's why
articles.summary: Migratory birds arrived in Bhitarkanika in the last week of December to escape the freezing conditions in far-off places beyond the Himalayas. They are already on their way back home due to a sudden rise in temperature and the early onset of summer in Odisha.

articles.title: Tens of thousands of residents forced out of their homes as once looming threat begins to wreak havoc: 'A ... crisis'
articles.author: Robert Crow
articles.summary: Rising sea levels in Papua New Guinea's Gulf province are a result of climate change. Half of the area's 80,000 residents have to move inland due to sand erosion caused by rising sea levels. There is a proposal to begin sand mining in the Gulf province, which activists fear will make the situation worse.

articles.title: 'World's fastest' continent could 'crash into' Asia and cause devastation
articles.author: Liam Mcinerney
articles.summary: Australia is moving northwards at a surprising speed and scientists warn it will collide with Asia in millions of years. The consequences of the collision will be monumental. There is already increased seismic activity in the region. Some experts fear kangaroos could become extinct if they shared the same land as Asia.

articles.title: Migratory birds leaving Bhitarkanika early with rise in temperature in Odisha: Official
articles.author: PTI
articles.summary: Migratory birds are leaving Bhitarakanika National Park early this year due to the rise in temperature and the onset of early summer in Odisha. The birds flew into the Bhitarkanika water bodies from places like Siberia in December last year to avoid the extremely cold weather conditions.

articles.title: Day 56
articles.author: Derek Gee Buffalo News
articles.summary: Day 56 is Feb. 25, 2025. Patches of sky reflect in the water as ice melts in Tonawanda Creek near St. Martin Lutheran Church in NorthTonawanda, NY, as the water is melting.       i
